heading: 2.1 Do you Need A Model at All?
text: project scoped tackling observable issue, collecting analyzing field data may enough make decision (analysis equal modeling). example:Problem: temporary work zone observed cause queues hour opening traffic. heading: 2.2 Should you use Microsimulation?
text:
Consider analogy signal warrants: Traffic signal warrants much preventing installation unnecessary signals helping determine traffic signals appropriate. formal “microsimulation warrants,” following questions help guide determine microsimulation may useful prevent many headaches. Microsimulation may useful answer YES following:Existing alternative scenarios modeled without microsimulation (.e. simpler analysis tools available analyzing scenarios).Non-microsimulation tools provide degree precision required project objectives.Experienced staff can commit extensive time project deal complexity data challenges come simulationTime budget allow detailed calibration existing conditions.Time budget allow error checking multiple simulation runs.area interest limited spatial temporal extents allow reasonable compute times per run.
purpose answer “big picture,” network-wide effects, microsimulation probably best choice. Large-scale alternatives may also rule microsimulation. Knowing purpose helps scope right type model model limits.

heading: 2.3 Additional Questions to Consider when Scoping
2.3.1 What is the Model purpose?
text: Models factor decision making process. Physical, financial, environmental, factors often play important roles traffic models. However, models serve purpose:Models help complex alternative analysis. alternatives safely efficently field tested, modeling can help evaluate alternatives. idea alternatives may considered helps scoping.Models conversation pieces. Models provide something talk discussing existing conditions alternatives. Detailed modeling involves gathering data discussions, can important model results . model gets people talking problems ideas, model probably worthwhile, even limitations.

heading: 2.3.2 What question(s) will the model answer?
text: Related model purpose, asking specific question model helps scope right model extents. focused question, better microsimulation. Asking “changing weaving configuration affect throughput?” better question something generic like “Level Service?” Generic questions can likely answered efficient means microsimulation.

heading: 2.3.3 What data is available?
text: Lack field data can rule microsimulation, severely limit accuracy. Without field data, model calibration may achievable, detracts models believability.

heading: 2.3.4 What scenarios are being considered?
text: Just existing year? Future years? scenario increases time effort complete microsimulation. Limit number scenarios scoping. example consider analyzing one two alternatives microsimulation. Small variations one alternative may worthwhile simulate.
